speaker: Martin
text: All right, now.  Quiet, it's getting ready to start.

speaker: Announcer
text: The following is a paid political announcement for Holden Thorpe.

speaker: Niles
text: You dragged us over here to see a commercial for Holden Thorpe?

speaker: Martin
text: Shh!

speaker: Frasier
text: The man is a fascist.  He's like Himmler without the whimsy.  _Niles laughs at this, but Martin taps Frasier on the head with his cane to shut him up.  Cut to the TV commercial, which shows an American flag and the title HOLDEN THORPE FOR CONGRESS._

speaker: Announcer
text: And now another American for Holden Thorpe.

speaker: Martin
text: [_on television_] Hi, I'm Marty Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear God.

speaker: Martin
text: [_on television_] For thirty years I was a cop walking The beat in Seattle.  Then my hip was shattered by an assassin's bullet - an assassin who wouldn't have been on the streets if it weren't for those bleeding hearts we sent to Congress.

speaker: Martin
text: I used to carry a gun.  Now I carry a cane.  I'm voting to elect Holden Thorpe.  He's running because I can't.

speaker: Martin
text: Well?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, Mr. Crane, I don't know what to say. I'm in a state of shock.

speaker: Niles
text: Aren't we all?

speaker: Daphne
text: I mean, you were wonderful! [_she hugs him_] This calls for a celebration.  What'll you have?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, give me a beer.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad... how did this happen?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I took a walk to the park last week and they were having a rally for Thorpe.  So I started to talk to one of his people and told him I was an ex-cop and the next thing you know they were shoving a camera in my face.

speaker: Frasier
text: This is appalling.  Those people are exploiting you.

speaker: Martin
text: No, they're not.  I like Thorpe.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, how could you support that odious little hosehead? I once heard him say, "Cancer aside, tobacco is good for the economy."

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I like him.  He's gonna put more cops on the street.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_bringing Martin his beer_] Yeah, well, it couldn't hurt. Now that everyone and his brother's walking around armed. Makes me glad we don't have so many guns in England.

speaker: Frasier
text: You don't need guns, you've got kidney pie. [_The phone rings_] Hello? [_to Martin_] It's Duke.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh!

speaker: Niles
text: Sherry?

speaker: Frasier
text: I couldn't possibly, Niles.  I'm too upset.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh yeah, yeah.  I'm glad you liked it, Duke.  Yeah, it was fun.  Hey, I got a lot of showbiz secrets to tell you.  You know they can make you cry on cue by pulling a hair out of your nose?  What?  Really?  Oh, guys, quick, over here- channel 14, they're running my other spot!  Hey, Duke, this one was my idea.  Remember when Lyndon Johnson lifted up his shirt to show his scar?

speaker: Martin
text: [_v.o._] Hi, I'm Marty Crane.  Crime isn't pretty.  And if you don't believe me, look at this!  _Niles and Frasier turn just in time to see whatever "this" is. They both gasp in horror.  FADE OUT_  _Scene Two -- Cafe Nervosa. Frasier is standing at the bar of the cafe.  A waitress comes up to take his order._

speaker: Waitress
text: Can I help you, sir?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, what are your specials today?

speaker: Waitress
text: Kenyan blend.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no, no.  Still poaching elephants over there. Got something else?

speaker: Waitress
text: Dark roast Brazilian.

speaker: Frasier
text: Not until they do something about the loss of our rainforests.

speaker: Waitress
text: Salvadoran?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I've never forgiven them for their human rights violations.

speaker: Waitress
text: Well, then we're down to the Hawaiian Kona blend.  Or, have they slaughtered too many macadamia nuts?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_gives her a look, then_] That'll be fine, thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I can't stand it.  I just walked by an electronics store and there in the window were twenty-two television sets and on every screen was Dad's... [_looks around_]...butt.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_nods_] I saw it.  I don't know which is worse - seeing his butt, or what it stands for.  I just can't believe that our father is actually endorsing that self-serving fearmonger. [_they sit at a table_]

speaker: Niles
text: I've been giving this a lot of thought.  And I realized Dad isn't the problem.  He's just supporting the candidate of his choice.  The problem lies with us.

speaker: Frasier
text: Us?  We haven't done anything.

speaker: Niles
text: Exactly.  "The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing."

speaker: Frasier
text: Edmund Burke.

speaker: Niles
text: I have that quotation in a frame.  I keep meaning to put it up in my office but I never seem to get around to it. [_the waitress brings Frasier's coffee_] Anyway, Frasier, I think the time has come for you and me to get involved.

speaker: Frasier
text: What are you suggesting?

speaker: Niles
text: I propose we throw our support behind Thorpe's opponent, Phil Patterson.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, of course I intend to vote for Patterson.

speaker: Niles
text: I had something a little more ambitious in mind.  I spoke to some people down at Patterson's headquarters this morning, and your name came up.  They'd like you to film a TV spot endorsing their candidate.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, listen.  I'd really love to help, but surely you must realize that as a radio psychiatrist, I can't take a chance of alienating my listeners.  The people that need my help might be reluctant to call in if they knew my political views.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I wish you'd at least think about it.  A candidate like this doesn't come along that often.  He's hard-working. He volunteers weekends at a soup kitchen.  He really cares about people.  Finally, a politician who believes in the things we believe in.

speaker: Boy
text: Buy a box of chocolate - send a kid to camp?

speaker: Niles
text: Excuse me, can't you see we're talking here?!   _Scene Three - KACL. Frasier is doing his show._

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you for your call, Susan.  We'll be right back after this message.

speaker: Thorpe
text: [_sound of sirens and guns_] Crime - it's epidemic. It strikes fast and it can strike you.  I'm Holden Thorpe. You should send me to Washington because...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_cutting off the sound_] It's better than having you here!

speaker: Roz
text: [_entering Frasier's booth_] Piece of work, isn't he?  He makes it sound like it's either vote for him or be found murdered in your bed.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I wouldn't be concerned if I were you, Roz.  What are the chances of finding you there alone?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hey, sports fan, how they hangin'?

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, Bulldog.

speaker: Bulldog
text: I was talking to Roz.  _Bulldog smacks Roz on the behind, and, as she spins round in fury, sticks his tongue out at her.  She grabs the tongue and smacks it with the sharp corner of the cart in her hand._

speaker: Roz
text: Ten seconds.  _She goes into her booth as Frasier turns up the volume on the commercial for Holden Thorpe._

speaker: Thorpe
text: So vote for me.  My crime program will give the streets back to the people-

speaker: Frasier
text: [_cuts it off; on air_] That's good.  Because with your tax program, that's where they'll be sleeping!  Welcome back, Seattle.  We'll be back for just one more phone call after this news break.  And then next up, Bob "Bulldog" Briscoe- [_Bulldog blows his whistle and bangs a gong in Frasier's ear_] and the Gonzo Sports Show. [_off air_] I've asked you not to do that!

speaker: Bulldog
text: Way to be impartial, Doc. [_honks horn_] You know, I happen to think Thorpe's a good man.  Who you voting for, that pretty boy Phil Patterson?

speaker: Roz
text: [_enters_] Yeah, Patterson's great.  His reapportionment plan makes a lot of sense.

speaker: Frasier
text: Forget it, Roz.  He's happily married.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_chuckling_] Yeah, so's Thorpe.  Go figure.  His wife's a cow and he still loves her.

speaker: Frasier
text: There's a bumper sticker.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Be back in a minute. [_leaves_]

speaker: Roz
text: [_through the glass_] Hey, I liked that little shot you took at Thorpe.  Although our next caller doesn't seem to share your opinion.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, really?  Well, put him on.  I welcome contrasting viewpoints. [_on air_] Hello, Seattle, we're back.  Roz, who do we have on the line?

speaker: Roz
text: On line one we have Holden Thorpe.

speaker: Roz
text: Go ahead, caller.

speaker: Thorpe
text: [_v.o._] Crane, Thorpe.  Let me ask you something.  Are you married?

speaker: Frasier
text: Divorced.

speaker: Thorpe
text: You ever serve in the military?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, actually, I have congenitally weak ankles, it's a family problem.

speaker: Thorpe
text: I see, I see.  So a guy like you - unmarried, didn't serve his country - sees fit to criticize a patriotic family man who fought in the Battle of Grenada.  I went in on the first wave, by the way.

speaker: Frasier
text: On a surfboard, I suppose?

speaker: Thorpe
text: If you ask me, the day we get the likes of you off the radio will be the day America will be a nice, friendly place to live again.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, you've said your piece, now you're gonna listen to mine! [_Thorpe hangs up_] Hang up on me, will you?!  Well, all right, even though you may not be listening, the people of Seattle are gonna hear what I have to say!

speaker: Roz
text: No, they won't.  The show ended five seconds ago, I had to send it to traffic.  _Frasier angrily throws off his headphones.  FADE TO:_  **CITIZEN CRANE**  _Scene Four - Frasier's apartment. Frasier is in the process of rehearsing a political commercial in his apartment. It's filled with lights and sound equipment and various crew.  Niles is among them.  Frasier is seated in the chair near the balcony door.  He is at first facing the balcony, but he then turns to face the camera._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hello there.  I'm Dr. Frasier Crane.  Many of you know me from my radio show, but today I'm speaking to you as a concerned citizen. [_stands_] As a mental health expert, I've been listening to what my good friend Phil Patterson has to say.  I like the way his mind works.  He's a visionary, and he cares about the little people.  That's why I'm proud to say that I'm behind Phil Patterson for Congress.

speaker: Phil
text: Thanks, Frasier. [_facing camera_] Together, we can live the dream.

speaker: Frasier
text: Phil Patterson: the sane choice.

speaker: Director
text: Okay, guys.  Give us about five minutes to adjust the lights and then we'll shoot it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Great.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, yes, adjust those lights.  They need to be, uh, lighter and... you know, brighter. _He trips over one of the lights.  A crewman grabs it before it falls and gives Niles a look.  Niles, Frasier and Phil walk over to the dinner table._

speaker: Phil
text: Thanks again, Frasier.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, our pleasure, Phil.  The Crane family has a long history of political involvement.  You know, my wife Maris actually has all our servants down at your campaign headquarters licking envelopes.  She'd do it herself, but the poor thing can't produce saliva.  _Niles exits to the kitchen as Frasier and Patterson share a look. Daphne then enters with Eddie._

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello, there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Daphne... I thought we agreed you'd keep him out of here for two hours.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I walked him around the park, but you know how he gets.  He starts whining and whimpering until you can't stand it any longer.

speaker: Phil
text: [_bending down to pet Eddie_] Oh, don't let them talk about you like that, little fella.

speaker: Martin
text: [_coming in the door_] She was talking about me.  Hi, Marty Crane.

speaker: Phil
text: Phil Patterson. [_they shake hands_] You look familiar, Mr. Crane, but I can't quite place you.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, let me give you a hint.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad! [_he shoos Martin away_]

speaker: Martin
text: Just trying to help the guy!

speaker: Frasier
text: My father did a commercial for your opponent.

speaker: Phil
text: Yes, it came back to me.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello, Daphne Moon.

speaker: Phil
text: Hi. [_shakes hands_]

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, my uncle was a political writer for one of those London tabloids.  I can still remember his biggest scoop. The headline read: "High-ranking politician caught wearing women's clothing."  Of course, you turn to page two and you found out it was Margaret Thatcher, but by then you'd already bought the paper.

speaker: Phil
text: [_struggling for words_] Well, thank you, Miss Moon. [_she leaves_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Say, Phil, it's getting a little hot in here.  You want to step out on to the balcony with me, get a little fresh air?

speaker: Phil
text: Great. [_as they walk out_] Oh, beautiful view.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.  Yes, you know, I feel very lucky living here. I'd like to say I feel lucky to be a part of your campaign as well.

speaker: Phil
text: Oh, it's me who's lucky.  It's quite a boost for an underdog to get an endorsement from Frasier Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I don't know if my name carries that much weight.

speaker: Phil
text: Oh, come on, people love you.  I've listened to your show. To tell the truth, I've even thought of calling in.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?  What for?

speaker: Phil
text: Oh, it's... kind of sensitive.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, Phil, as a psychiatrist, anything you tell me will be kept in the strictest confidence. _Phil still hesitates.  They both stare out at the view, not looking at each other._

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, it's funny how the more you bottle things up inside, the bigger they seem to be.

speaker: Phil
text: Well, I've never told anybody this before, but... okay, here goes.  Six years ago... I was abducted by aliens.  _Frasier, shocked, slowly turns his head to face Phil. He is completely stunned._

speaker: Frasier
text: Aliens?

speaker: Phil
text: They transported me up to their spaceship for a kind of conference.  They're very concerned about what we're doing to our planet. [_Frasier stares at Phil_] Hey, you were right. Now that I've said it out loud, it doesn't seem like that big a deal.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_far away_] No...

speaker: Niles
text: They're ready for you, gentlemen.  Come on in here and let's elect a Congressman!

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier? [_He gestures for Frasier to come in, but he doesn't move_] Frasier?  _END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO_  **LET'S JUST KEEP THIS UNDER OUR SPACE HELMETS**  _Scene One - Frasier's apartment. It is a few moments after Phil's revelation. Frasier is now filming the political commercial.  He looks mortified._

speaker: Director
text: We're rolling.  And... action.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_in his chair_] Hello, I'm Dr. Frasier Crane. Many of you know me from my radio show but today I'm speaking to you as a concerned citizen... a deeply concerned citizen.

speaker: Frasier
text: As a mental health expert, I've been listening to what my good friend Phil Patterson has to say. [_stands_] I like the way his mind works.  He's a visionary, and he cares about... [_whimpering_] ...the little people.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's why I'm proud to say that I'm behind Phil Patterson for Congress.

speaker: Phil
text: Thanks, Frasier. [_shakes his hand and faces the camera_] Together, we can live the dream.

speaker: Frasier
text: Phil Patterson: [_almost in tears_] The sane choice.

speaker: Director
text: Okay, cut it!

speaker: Frasier
text: God, I'm burning up!

speaker: Director
text: Frasier, you were a little nervous on that one. Why don't you take a couple of minutes and we'll try it again.

speaker: Martin
text: I got mine on the first take.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, may I see you in the kitchen?

speaker: Niles
text: What's going on in there?  You look like a zombie!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh God, Niles!  I've got something I'd really like to get off my chest. [_sits at a bar stool_] But if I told you I'd be violating a doctor-patient confidence.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I see.  Well, nothing is more sacrosanct than our professional ethics. [_sits opposite Frasier_] Fortunately, I know a trick to get around them.  For the next few minutes, I'll be your psychiatrist, and then you can spill your guts with impunity.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's borderline, but I'm desperate!

speaker: Niles
text: All right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just now, on the balcony, Phil Patterson told me that he had been... abducted by aliens. [_Niles stares_] Apparently, he was beamed up to the mother ship, for a little interplanetary chitchat!  _Niles leans around to look outside the kitchen.  He then leans back to look at Frasier._

speaker: Niles
text: This is bad, isn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, this is incredible.  It's just awful.  We're gonna look like such idiots!

speaker: Niles
text: We?!  The whole thing was your idea.  I knew I should never have let you get me into politics!

speaker: Frasier
text: My idea?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh my God, Niles, stop it!  This isn't getting us anywhere!

speaker: Niles
text: All right, what are we going to do?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I think we have to convince Phil to drop out of the race and seek professional help.

speaker: Niles
text: If Phil drops out, then Thorpe will win.

speaker: Frasier
text: Forget it, Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, then you can forget education, and the environment, and funding for the arts...

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you saying I should still back Phil?

speaker: Niles
text: All right.  Answer me this: can you tell me with any certainty that in such a vast universe there isn't intelligent life on other planets?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_glares_] At the moment, I'm not sure there's intelligent life in this kitchen!

speaker: Niles
text: All right, all right, all right.  Let's assume that it's in his imagination.  How often does he see these aliens?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's only happened the one time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Which might suggest that it was an isolated incident brought on by overwork rather than a pattern of paranoid delusion.

speaker: Niles
text: My diagnosis exactly!

speaker: Frasier
text: Phil has worked hard.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: He deserves his chance.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: He's still gotta seek professional help.

speaker: Niles
text: [_forceful_] Yes!  The best there is.  But we're not going to turn our backs on him three weeks before the election.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, damn it, we are not. [_they shake hands_] So, will you treat him?

speaker: Niles
text: [_as they exit_] Are you kidding?  I'm a doctor, not a miracle worker! **THE FAULT LIES NOT IN OUR STARS, BUT IN OURSELVES**  _Scene Two - KACL. Frasier and Roz are in her booth during a commercial break. She is plucking her eyebrows._

speaker: Roz
text: I think it's time I get my eyebrows waxed.  I'm starting to get that Romanian peasant look again.  Of course, it doesn't help that I didn't get any sleep last night.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dating a snorer?

speaker: Roz
text: You know, Frasier, I'm getting just a little tired of your constant insinuation that I sleep around.  I didn't get any sleep because of that idiot Chopper Dave.  When he gets bored doing traffic reports he likes to buzz people's apartments in his helicopter.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I can see how that would be annoying.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, it didn't bother me much, but the guy I was with is a Vietnam vet and he started having flashbacks.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Greetings, losers!  Have you heard the great news?

speaker: Frasier
text: What, one of your overpaid idols passed his urine test?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Yeah, laugh all you can.  Word's out about your pal Patterson and those aliens of his.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, my God!

speaker: Roz
text: What aliens?

speaker: Bulldog
text: It's all over TV!

speaker: Frasier
text: How did they find out?

speaker: Bulldog
text: What, are you kidding?  You can't keep something like this quiet.  Every station in town is serving his bleeding heart up on a platter.

speaker: Frasier
text: Isn't that just like the media?  The day before the election they find one tiny flaw in a man and they try to ruin his career!  Well, you know what?  I have my own conduit to the public's ear.  I'm not letting Phil go down without a fight! [_he storms into his booth_]

speaker: Roz
text: What aliens?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Turns out Patterson's got a couple of illegal aliens from Guatemala working in his house.  No greencards, no documents, no chance!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_on air_] Hello, Seattle. I'm back.  This is Dr. Frasier Crane and I have just learned during the commercial break that it has become public knowledge that Phil Patterson, candidate for Congress, believes in aliens from outer space.

speaker: Frasier
text: Not only does he believe in them, he believes he has met with them.  That he was beamed aboard their spaceship for a little interplanetary t�te-�-t�te. [_Roz shakes her head at him to stop_] Shocked?  Well, all right. [_Roz knocks on the glass, he ignores her_] But I say, let's ask ourselves these questions. Has this...  _Roz pounds on the glass and slashes a finger across her throat. He waves her off and continues._

speaker: Frasier
text: ...harmless delusion, most likely brought on by overwork and sleep deprivation, adversely affected his voting record in any way?  I ask you, and I say no.  What great leader doesn't have his quirks?  Ronald Reagan saw an astrologist.  General Patton believed in reincarnation.  Even J. Edgar Hoover let his slip show once in a while!  [_N.B. To be fair, if Ronald Reagan ever saw an astrologist, it's because Nancy asked him to. -- Mike Lee_]

speaker: Frasier
text: People, we're talking about a great leader here!  We shouldn't concern ourselves with these minor eccentricities. What's important - what really counts - is what's in here... I'm pointing at my chest now.  _Roz rolls her eyes and buries her face in her hands as the scene fades out.  FADE TO:_  **ONE PERSON SPEAKING OUT _CAN_ MAKE A DIFFERENCE**  _Scene Three - Frasier's apartment. It's the evening of the election.  Daphne and Martin are watching the results.  Frasier is sitting near the balcony, defeated._

speaker: Announcer
text: The results from the last precinct are in.  Holden Thorpe has been elected to Congress, garnering a whopping ninety- two percent of the vote.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, at least Mr. Patterson got eight percent.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, well, they must have been counting absentee votes from the planet Krypton!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, come on now, Dr. Crane.  It wasn't all your fault.  I'm sure having those Guatemalans in his home would have cost him some votes anyway. [_exits_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Those Guatemalans were exchange students!  Phil was giving them free room and board as a goodwill gesture between countries.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I'd like to stay here and gloat, but I gotta get changed to go to the big celebration down at Thorpe headquarters.  Hey, you're welcome to tag along if you'd like.  You're quite a hero down there!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, thank you. [_he hits himself on the forehead_] Stupid, stupid, stupid! [_then_] When will I learn it hurts when I do that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Phil.  Come on in.

speaker: Phil
text: Hi Frasier.  Thank you.  I just came by to return this good- luck tie you loaned me. [_hands him the tie_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, I saw you wearing it on television when you made your concession speech.

speaker: Phil
text: It was a little embarrassing having to do it before lunch. But it gave me some time to run some errands and pick up my dry cleaning.

speaker: Frasier
text: Phil, I am so sorry about the misunderstanding...

speaker: Phil
text: Oh, it's okay.  I know you didn't do it on purpose.  You thought you were defending me.

speaker: Frasier
text: The people of Seattle deserve something better than Holden Thorpe.

speaker: Phil
text: That's politics.  And it's just one election.  I'll be back.

speaker: Frasier
text: You really think you can?

speaker: Phil
text: Maybe I'm a dreamer, but I like to believe anything's possible. [_he starts to leave_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Phil?  I've gotta ask you... do you really believe it happened?

speaker: Phil
text: I honestly wish I could say it didn't, but it did.  I guess you'll never believe it unless it happens to you.

speaker: Frasier
text: So, what's next for you?

speaker: Phil
text: Maybe I'll run in California.  A thing like this could actually help me there.  _Phil leaves.  Frasier shuts the door and walks over to where he laid the tie.  He picks it up for a moment and appears thoughtful. He then puts the tie down and walks up to the balcony door to look out._

speaker: Frasier
text: Anything's possible... _Suddenly, a bright light fills the sky.  Frasier frantically looks out to see what it could be.  He opens the door and looks up into the sky._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, very funny, Chopper Dave!
